if Statements

　The if statement is a syntax that determines whether or not to execute a part of the script by conditional judgment, such as "If XX, do AA".
　The syntax is as follows:

if(expression)
    Statement/block
else
    Statement/block
　The first "statement or block" is executed when the result of evaluating expression is true, and the second "statement or block" is executed when the result of evaluation is false. If you don't need it after else, you don't have to write it.

Usage:
    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are equal");

    if(a<b)
    {
        var t;
        t=a; a=b; b=t; //swap a and b
    }

    if(a==b)
        inform("a and b are equal");
    else
        inform("a and b are not equal");

Correspondence between if and else

　else has the rule "corresponds to the previous if that does not yet correspond to else".

For example, if you write this code:

    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
        else // ●
            statement;
    else // ★
        statement;
　here, the else of ★ corresponds to the if of ★, and the else of ● corresponds to the if of ●.
　It should be noted that freestyle languages like TJS2...
    if(expr) // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    else // ●
        statement;
　have the same correspondence as above, even if the indent is written incorrectly.
　If you want to clearly separate the statement blocks,

    if(expr) { // ★
        if(expr) // ●
            statement;
    }
    else // ★
        statement;
　enclose it in {} like so.
